Dear {!Contact.FirstName} {!Contact.LastName},
Thank you for contacting LegalZoom for your business needs. In regard to your inquiry, LegalZoom can assist you in forming your Corporation or Doing Business As (DBA) name. We simplify the process for you by preparing and filing the necessary documents with your respective state agency to complete the registration.
To help you make an informed decision, provided below is a comparison of Corporations and DBAs and some of the similarities and differences between them. If you would like to get specific, detailed information on your personal situation, please contact a Business Formation Specialist at the phone number listed below. By speaking with a Specialist will be able to assist with answering further questions, as well as building a customized package to best benefit your needs.
If you intend on conducting business under a name different from your personal name, you may consider filing a DBA (Doing Business As) name. A DBA will allow you to conduct business under the registered name, open a business bank account, obtain licenses and permits, and hire employees. A DBA, however, does not provide name exclusivity or liability protection, thus your personal assets may be liable in the event of a business lawsuit or bankruptcy.
If liability is a concern, you may consider forming a Corporation. Corporations are state-specific business entities that provide several advantages as a business structure. Corporations are separate and distinct legal entities that provide the people involved in the business with personal liability protection, separating personal assets from business assets. This liability protection shields personal assets from any debts or liabilities that are incurred by the business. Corporations also provide name exclusivity in the state in which it is registered, ensuring that other Corporations and LLCs cannot use the same business name in the state.
Corporations do have formalities that must be upheld as part of the operations of a Corporation. Corporations are required to designate directors, officers, and shareholders, although one person can hold all necessary positions. Corporations also require to that annual shareholder and director meetings be held and written minutes of these meetings must be kept on company records.
DBAs are taxed as pass-through entities, and typically report business income and expenses with the owner's personal tax return(s), while Corporations file a separate corporate tax return. A Corporation must choose a specific tax designation, either to be taxed as a C-Corporation, or as an S-Corporation. You may choose to be taxed as a pass-through entity (such as a sole proprietorship or partnership), as a C-Corporation, or as an S-Corporation. C-Corporations are subject to double taxation, meaning that profits are taxed at the corporate level, and possibly taxed a second time at the individual level. S-Corporations are subject to single-taxation, and are taxed similarly to pass-through entities, while potentially providing more tax benefits than a pass-through entity. For further information on tax structure, please consult an accountant or CPA.
